isis.stitle: Recall 00503 - Power Steering Pumps Installed on T 444E V-8 Engines in Vehicles Built 2/1/2000 Through 3/24/2000

recall.subject: Power Steering Pumps Installed on T 444E V-8 Engines in Vehicles Built 2/1/2000 Through 3/24/2000

defect.para: A power steering pump defect was found that can cause a loss of fluid flow. The power steering pump is designed to provide power assist to both the steering system and the hydraulic braking system. A defective pump may reduce the fluid flow to less than the minimum required flow rate to provide full power assist to the brake system with low engine speed. This defect may cause an increase in both stopping distance and steering wheel efforts during steering and braking maneuvers at slow engine speeds; therefore, increasing the possibility of an accident, which may result in property damage, personal injury, or death.
This campaign covers 3400, 3800, 1652 SC, RE Bus, RE CMRCL, 4700 4 X 2, 4700 LPX and 4700 LP models built 2/01/2000 through 3/24/2000.

ownernote.para: International Truck and Engine Corporation will notify owners of this campaign on their vehicles. During the recall process, a listing of owner names and addresses will be furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners and have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.stitle: Recall 00503 - Power Steering Pumps Installed on T 444E V-8 Engines in Vehicles Built 2/1/2000 Through 3/24/2000
svcproc.title: SERVICE PROCEDURE

warning.para: To prevent serious eye injury, ALWAYS wear safe eye protection when you perform vehicle maintenance or service.
Block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving.

para.emph: Please read the following steps carefully before proceeding.

step1.para: INSPECTION:Read both A. and B. below before replacing the pump.

step2.para: DEFECTIVE PUMPS: The casting numbers should be cleaned and read before the pump is removed. Defective casting numbers end with a dot nine (.9) or a dot ten (.10) (see FIGURE 1). Both the dot and the number 9 or 10 are easily readable. SPECIAL NOTE: The casting numbers ending in a 9 or 10 must have a dot ( . ) in front of the 9 or the 10 and not a backslash ( / ). Read B. and continue to Step 2. (PUMP REPLACEMENT PROCEDURE) if necessary.

GOOD PUMPS: All pumps ending in a number other than a 9 or a 10 should be considered good pumps, and pumps that have casting numbers ending in a backslash nine ( /9 ) or a backslash ten ( /10 ) are good.

figure.caption: Figure 1 - DEFECTIVE PUMP SAMPLE: This defective pump has a casting number ending with a dot ten (.10).

svcproc.stitle: Recall 00503 - Power Steering Pumps Installed on T 444E V-8 Engines in Vehicles Built 2/1/2000 Through 3/24/2000
svcproc.title: 2. PUMP REPLACEMENT PROCEDURE

step1.para: Shut off engine and block the wheels to prevent the vehicle from moving.
Prepare for fluid loss and remove both hoses at the pump.

note.para: Moving the steering wheel after the hoses are disconnected will allow more air into the hydraulic system; therefore, do not move the steering wheel after removing hoses from pump.

step1.para: Remove the two pump mounting nuts and remove the pump from the studs. Return all defective pumps to Fort Wayne, Indiana per the instructions on the R-5185 (PDA)
Note the orientation of the fittings on the pump and remove the fittings from the pump.

Clean the hose fittings, remove both old o-rings from the fittings, pre-lube new o-rings with clean PS fluid, carefully install the o-rings on the fittings, make sure o-rings are seated, and re-install the fittings in the new pump in the original orientation.

note.para: Carefully avoid pinching or twisting the new o-rings when re-installing.

step1.para: Discard the old pump o-ring and install new o-ring on pump casting, pre-lube with grease to hold in place, and re-install pump on mounting studs. Tighten the mounting nuts to 46-56 FT-LBS.
Top-off reservoir with International PS fluid and replace cap.

Start engine and let idle, turn the wheels fully left and hold hard for up to 5 seconds, then turn the wheels fully right and hold hard for up to 5 seconds. Repeat these full cycle turns three times and stop with the wheels straight ahead. Shut off engine and top-off reservoir.
Continue operation in Step 2 until correct level is attained.
Run engine at fast RPM and continue to turn wheels back and forth slowly for approximately 5 minutes. Again top-off reservoir to the correct level, replace cap, and check for leaks in hoses.
Return all defective pumps to Fort Wayne, Indiana per the instructions on the R-5185 (PDA).

partsinfo.para: An estimated 9% of the vehicles in this campaign will require a new power steering pump. Please keep these details in mind when ordering parts. To replace a pump you will need one of each part number except the nut part number. The nut part number is provided in case you would need an extra part.

entry.para: Pressure hose o-ring at pump end, hose on side of pump
Return hose o-ring at pump end, hose on top of pump
10mm Flange Headed Nut, reusable nuts, part number for information only

note.para: ALL DEFECTIVE PUMPS MUST BE RETURNED TO FORT WAYNE, INDIANA PER THE INSTRUCTIONS ON THE R-5185 (PDA).

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified IMMEDIATELY from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.
However, consistent with the customer notification, dealers are expected to complete the repairs on the mutually agreed upon service date.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair his or her vehicle as soon as possible.
